Eli Lotar: the realist surrealist – in pictures Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email View more sharing options Share on LinkedIn Share on Pinterest Share on Google+ Share on WhatsApp Share on Messenger Close 
This French photographer and filmmaker documented everyday scenes – but invested them with the visual daring of the surrealist movement

Monday 6 February 2017 07.00 GMT 
Asleep, Spain, Fourth Journey, February 1936 
With images full of dread and dark wit, French photographer Eli Lotar perched brilliantly between surrealism and documentary. An exhibition, Eli Lotar (1905-1969) , is at Jeu de Paume, Paris, 14 February-28 May. All images: Eli Lotar Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
The Meat, 1929 
Lotar was born in Paris in 1905, the son of a Romanian poet. He grew up in Bucharest, but returned to Paris and became a French citizen in 1926 Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Punishment, 1929 
He became involved in the radical arts scene of Paris in the 1920s, befriending theatre directors such as Antonin Artaud and Roger Vitrac, and writers Jacques and Pierre Prévert Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Untitled (Broken Glass), circa 1940-1950 
He also worked with the surrealist filmmaker Luis Buñuel, and was the cinematographer for his only documentary, Las Hurdes: Tierra Sin Pan (Land Without Bread) Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Madrid, February 1936 
His work appeared in a variety of radical publications, including George Bataille’s journal Documents – his images of hooves illustrate the word abattoir in the ‘dictionary’ section Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Hôpital des Quinze-Vingts, 1928 
Lotar’s, whose work was visually daring and more socially engaged than that of many other surrealists, used photography to document the dramas and struggles of everyday French people Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Draining of the Zuiderzee, Netherlands, 1930 
He moved into directing his own films, including Aubervilliers (1945), a collaged study of the Parisian suburb commissioned by the city’s mayor to highlight poor living conditions. It screened at the Cannes film festival Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Untitled (Journey Aboard the L’Exir Dallen), circa 1933 
Lotar worked as a cameraman for French film luminaries such as Jean Renoir and Jean Painlevé Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Untitled (Lisbonne), 1931 
Another collaborator was the surrealist photographer Germaine Krull, who also became Lotar’s lover – although he later married Elisabeth Makovski Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Giacometti, Bust of Lotar, 1965 
In his later life, he befriended the great sculptor Alberto Giacometti, and posed for him in some of Giacometti’s final pieces Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
Portrait of the Actress Wanda Vangen, 1929 
Lotar died in 1969, leaving behind a body of work that brings together glamour, storytelling, urban realism and fantasy Facebook Twitter Pinterest
